newsitem.title: USA: Gray leaf spot not seen hurting U.S. corn yields.
newsitem.headline: Gray leaf spot not seen hurting U.S. corn yields.

text.p: Gray leaf spot, a fungal disease that damages corn leaves, has spread across the U.S. Corn Belt but isn't expected to have much of an impact on yields this fall, crop experts said.

"It's all over, but I don't think it's that severe in most locations," said Donald White, professor of plant pathology at the University of Illinois. "Last year, it looked like we had more disease at this time."
Gray leaf spot, or GLS, needs high humidity, moderate temperatures and frequent rains to flourish.
The disease "got off to a real heavy start" early this summer when rains doused much of the eastern Corn Belt, but recent cool, dry conditions have limited its spread, White said.
Gary Munkvold, extention plant pathologist at Iowa State University, doubted GLS would cause much yield loss in Iowa.
"Frost is probabaly a much bigger threat to yield than gray leaf spot," he said. "I don't think gray leaf spot is going to stack up as a big factor in comparison."
He said the disease was widespread across the state but was especially prevalent in southeast Iowa.

But GLS doesn't pose much of a threat because only a small percentage of corn plants have GLS lesions on middle and upper leaves, which play a vital role in nourishing the plant as it reaches maturity.

"For the most part, it's confined to the lower leaves," said David Wysong, University of Nebraska extension plant pathologist. "It's not going to have an impact on yields so long as it's confined to the lower leaves. It's the mid and upper leaves that actually fill the grain."
Wysong said GLS infestation was most heavy in the eastern third and south-central part of Nebraska but had been found "in just about every county that produces corn."
The disease has also been reported in Indiana and Ohio.

Pathologists linked the rising incidence of GLS to conservation tillage because the fungus thrives on crop debris. Farmers can limit the disease by using convential tillage, planting GLS-tolerant corn hybrids or spraying crops with a fungicide.
